body: The default stack size for musl-libc is 128kb, which is smaller than the largest stack allocations in toxcore. We should try to keep stack allocations well below this limit in order to avoid stack overflows on musl builds. Using the compiler flag `-Wlarger-than=2000` we can see that after this change the largest stack allocation is now just over 2kb. It's worth noting that musl versions >= 1.22 allow us to increase the stack size by setting the LDFLAGS: `-Wl,-z,stack-size=` --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/1664)

why are you using malloc and not calloc?

> why are you using malloc and not calloc?

Because calloc is considerably slower and zero-initializing the buffers is unnecessary.

on todays architecture (raspi and x86 linux) malloc is an alias to calloc anyways. rapi has even assembler hand optimised calloc.
and why is it not necessary to zero init?

> on todays architecture (raspi and x86 linux) malloc is an alias to calloc anyways

The only assumptions we should make about the behaviour of malloc is how it's defined in the standard. Multi-platform software shouldn't rely on platform-specific optimizations.

> and why is it not necessary to zero init?

Because the uninitialized memory is never read.

This PR touches the code that ends up in bootstrapd, so can you please update the checksum? (to 6891f36d5b83902382e11c030df5966a6a64572f057ca8567456ccb5593556d4)

If you want to verify/update the checksum, you can run ./other/bootstrap_daemon/docker/update-sha256

https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/master/other/bootstrap_daemon/docker/tox-bootstrapd.sha256

commit.message:
Use heap memory instead of stack for large variables

The default stack size for musl-libc is 128kb. Therefore we should try to keep stack
allocations well below this limit in order to avoid stack overflows.

Use heap memory instead of stack for large variables

The default stack size for musl-libc is 128kb. Therefore we should try to keep stack
allocations well below this limit in order to avoid stack overflows.
